comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Something not quite right here. The trusses and decking don't seem to exist on any other pictures of the wonderful Gundagai railway (and road) bridges (well worth a visit if you are nearby). I think this picture is of another bridge altogether, as are the two companion photos in State Records, investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... and investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... Ref. - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gundagai,_New_South_Wales#Bridges_o... So if is not Gundagai, I wonder where it is?

comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Apparently a new railway bridge opened in 1902, replacing an older one. There is also a view of the bridge by the Charles Kerry studio dated as 1875 - 1897 at the National Library of Australia which gives a wonderfully long view of the bridge. It is not a match with the one shown in the photograph above. see here: nla.gov.au/nla.pic-vn4312996 Here's another old view of the two bridges: nla.gov.au/nla.pic-an8526479-826

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: It is interesting that the 2nd linked photograph by beachcomberaustralia above ( investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... ) does show a road bridge adjacent to a rail bridge which happens to be similar to the arrangement of the Gundagai bridges over the Murrumbidgee River's flood plain. Here's a modern view of the way the bridges run nearby each other: www.flickr.com/photos/47932052@N03/4509896547/in/faves-li...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Was there really an old Gundagai railway bridge? The railway reached Gundagai in 1885/1886 from Cootamundra to the north without the need for a bridge. Why would they go to the expense of building a line across the flood plain and across the Murrumbidgee River to South Gundagai before the extension of the line to Tumut in 1902/1903? Could this be where the second photo beachcomberaustralia linked was taken, from South Gundagai looking north over the Murrumbidgee River? Perhaps, but I don't think so. I am sure this is about where the second photo BobMeade linked was taken, from Gundagai proper looking south over Morleys Creek. But I could be wrong ... In any event, this may be of interest: The Murrumbidgee Valley Rail Trail Feasibility Study

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy]  Unfortunately that NLA picture, which is very definitely of the 1867 Prince Albert ROAD bridge, is also misnamed.  I am not sure how to let the NLA know.  All very confusing.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet]  I too think it is not a replacement rail bridge.  Your link for the MVRTFS above has a detailed history of the line under "Section 2 - Background".

It is easy to understand how the naming mistake on State Record's three photos happened with the similar layout and geography, but where is it, if not Gundagai?   Maybe it is not a rail bridge due to the decking?  Any rail / bridge experts out there?

comment.author: 47201412@N02

Actually, you'd be interested to know I identified this and noted this was uploaded back to front in 2006. Interesting as I think you have referenced these artworks in previous posts.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Thanks, I have written to the NLA, and I am suitably impressed by your achievements.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Potted History of Gundagai - www.gundagai.nsw.gov.au/about/1000/1001.html I'm continually astounded by the sheer amount of fascinating Australian local history that I've never before heard. Too often we focus on the big narrative. My mind delightfully boggles at the thought of what I'm yet to encounter. But thanks to [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/]'s posts they're slowly revealing themselves ...

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
Hi All, many of the GPO prints were 'identified' prior to transfer to State Records many years ago and we take on trust the accuracy of that identification. However mistakes are made and we are grateful that public forums like Flickr allow for images to be correctly identified. 

To quote beachcomberaustralia 'where is it, if not Gundagai?'   We hope you all haven't given up on the challenge of identifying the bridge :)

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Yes, that is the question. Where? Here is a pamphlet about the history of timber bridges in New South Wales generally, although it does not specifically help to identify this bridge. But I'm sure we'll need the information one day. www.rta.nsw.gov.au/environment/downloads/heritage/bridge-... There is a slight chance that this monograph describes of has a pic of this bridge: search.informit.com.au/documentSummary;dn=314643020470120... Here is a list of heritage bridges (not necessarily exhaustive) in NSW, almost all with photographs. I've checked every listed timber bridge photograph, and none match this bridge: www.visit.heritage.nsw.gov.au/16_subnav_09_1.cfm

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Now, this is not the same bridge as the second one, but it is an identical design acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=413973

comment.author: 47932052@N03
comment._content: I have attached a photograph from 1896, which i found in a journal published by the Department of Main Roads in September 1951. Which shows the road bridge at Gundagai under reconstruction. www.flickr.com/photos/47932052@N03/4998707472/ I also agree it is unlikely this photograph is from Gundagai.

comment.author: 47932052@N03
comment._content: Here is another photo of the two bridges in 1931 from the Museum of Victoria. museumvictoria.com.au/collections/itemimages/067/218/6721...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/47932052@N03] Hi Sandbunny2010 - that photo from the Museum of Victoria shows the bridges from the north, looking south across the flood plain towards South Gundagai.

If only we could identify the location of this bridge - but now that we have 4 flickr users on the case our odds have improved! :)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Having declared that these three pictures are NOT GUNDAGAI, I feel slightly responsible for finding where the two bridges are or were, and any information or ideas are welcome. My latest idea is that the new bridge may be a replacement for the old (ie. both are road bridges), and the new bridge has a yet-to-be-installed metal lifting section like the bridge at Hinton or Dunmore to allow steamers underneath. The flat landscape beyond looks more like the Hunter Valley and Paterson River region. The central span in the three photos looks like a temporary structure with strange wooden piers down to the water, This bridge has curved arched trusses, which makes me think it is earlier than the straight trusses used on most later bridges. I also think that may be Percy Allandressed smartly in two of the photos, inspecting his trusses.

comment.author: 56648984@N05
comment._content: As a bridge design engineer and NSW bridge historian (self-proclaimed), I am quite certain the photograph is of the second Cowra bridge across the Lachlan River, constructed in 1893 and demolished in 1986. This bridge replaced an 1870 structure.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/56648984@N05] bridgeman8686! This is so exciting - I do believe you've solved our little mystery! The description fits - Australian Heritage Database - Place ID: 15931 And so does the appearance - Traffic bridge, Lachlan River, Cowra, New South Wales (c.1900-1940) by Murray Views [NLA: nla.pic-vn3293249] And part of the central span is preserved in a local park! - Historic bridge span (1893), Edgell Park Cowra (1996) by Brendon Kelson [NLA: nla.pic-an12275588-29]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/56648984@N05] B R I L L I A N T ! At last! Thank You bridgeman8686! More technical info - www.timberbuilding.arch.utas.edu.au/projects/view_project... . J.A. MacDonald was the engineer, not Percy Allan - it might be him in the photos. Since the bridge is not completed in all three pictures, I would say 1892. No more sleepless nights!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Read all about it - the opening ceremony (SMH Thursday 14/9/1893) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13927411 . John Wishart was the contractor. Is he in the photos? It cost 30,115 Pounds. Roughly $30 million today. "... the deck is formed of tallowwood planking diagonally on the carriage-way ..."

comment.author: 56648984@N05
comment._content: I'm familiar with the configuration of steel truss railway bridges in NSW and am fairly sure the bridge above is not located in NSW.  The triple cast iron cylindrical piers look more like a Queensland design.  In NSW, the pier cylinders were significantly larger in diameter.  Also, the timber beam approach spans are not of typical NSW design, based on the corbels above the timber trestles being too thin and not of square cross-section.
